Religious war is easy to whip up. Race war,too. Once the killing starts, even "reasonable" people can be scared into joining in; viz. the recent spike in gun sales. War is designed to keep those who are gorging themselves on opulence in the catbird seat.

I'm a good, card-carrying liberal. I do not own guns. But lately I find myself imagining that I am in a mall, or a market, or some other public place when one or more people come in with assault weapons and start firing at random. I imagine my emotions. Utter shock. Fear. And then a survival instinct kicks in. How do I protect myself? And then the next thought. I wish I had a gun.

One of the survivors of the San Bernardino massacre who had worked with Farooq stated in a TV interview that he wished that he had possession of a gun during the attack. He said that he did not know how much good it would have done, but at least he would have known that he tried.

The question is whether we have reached the tipping point where good public policy is outweighed by the reality that there are already more than 300 million guns in this country and that a personal policy to be able to protect one's self and family is paramount. And, quite frankly, I am very uncomfortable thinking this way.

When I was a kid, my father taught me how to fight. He was very clear. Never start a fight, but you do need to know how to protect yourself. Well, I'm pretty old these days and I'm not too interested in getting in any fist fights, but if I needed to try to protect myself, I would still do so. But fists are no match for a gun.

Asylum status isn't the same as refugee status. Likewise, neither the 9/11 hijackers nor the San Bernadino shooters were refugees. In other words, you tried to refute the assertion that "...nobody who got into the US by claiming refugee status has been involved in terrorism." with cases that involved people who didn't claim refugee status.

The proposal with which you closed your comment has no reasonable basis.

That Wikipedia reference shows he came here (as a child) with his family on a tourist visa and was subsequently granted political asylum. Russia continues to treat its Chechen citizens as refuse and virtually any one of them could legitimately be regarded as a political refugee.  In any case, the Tsarnaevs were not from the Middle East (neither Chechnya nor Kyrgyzstan is situated in that region), but even if they were it's no less absurd to claim that Muslims from that area "have a long history of terrorism" as it is to suggest that Jews have a long history of usury.  As for declining to admit refugees from countries on the terrorism list (i.e., the very people who are trying to get OUT of those countries), you might want to express those sentiments to Senator Rubio and Senator Cruz so they can propose that we stop Cuban refugees from entering the U.S.

What isn't far fetched, and we may yet hear about it, is that Syed Farook may have been pushed into radicalization, and then over the edge by a religious zealot bully at his place of employment.

To paint all Muslims, all 1.5 billion of them on this planet, with a terrorist brush, is racist.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dzhokhar_Tsarnaev
